Database Management System.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157501**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Database System Architecture (8 hrs)**
Data Abstraction, Data Independence, Data Definition Language (DDL), Data Manipulation Language (DML). Data Models: Entity-Relationship Model, Network Model, Relational Model and Object-Oriented Data Models, Integrity Constraints, Data Manipulation Operations.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Relational Query Languages & Database Design (10 hrs)**
Relational Algebra, Tuple Relational Calculus, Domain Relational Calculus, SQL3, DDL and DML Constructs. Open Source and Commercial DBMS: MySQL, Oracle, DB2, SQL Server.
Relational Database Design: Domain and Data Dependency, Armstrongâ€™s Axioms, Normal Forms, Dependency Preservation, Lossless Design.
Query Processing and Optimization: Evaluation of Relational Algebra Expressions, Query Equivalence, Join Strategies, Query Optimization Algorithms.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Storage Strategies (4 hrs)**
Indices, B-Trees, Hashing.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Transaction Processing (8 hrs)**
Concurrency Control, ACID Properties, Serializability of Schedules, Lock-Based and Timestamp-Based Schedulers, Multiversion and Optimistic Concurrency Control Schemes, Database Recovery.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Database Security (6 hrs)**
Authentication, Authorization and Access Control, DAC, MAC and RBAC Models, Intrusion Detection, SQL Injection.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Advanced Topics (6 hrs)**
Object-Oriented and Object-Relational Databases, Logical Databases, Web Databases, Distributed Databases, Data Warehousing and Data Mining.

ðŸ“š **Text / Reference Books**
1. Database System Concepts (6th Edition) â€” Abraham Silberschatz, Henry F. Korth, S. Sudarshan, McGraw-Hill
2. Principles of Database and Knowledge-Base Systems (Vol-1) â€” J. D. Ullman, Computer Science Press
3. Fundamentals of Database Systems (5th Edition) â€” R. Elmasri, S. Navathe, Pearson Education
4. Foundations of Databases â€” Serge Abiteboul, Richard Hull, Victor Vianu, Addison-Wesley

Artificial Intelligence.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157502**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Introduction (7 hrs)**
Overview of Artificial Intelligence, Turing Test, Intelligent Agents.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Problem Solving â€“ Search Techniques (7 hrs)**
Solving Problems by Searching: Uninformed Search â€“ Depth First Search (DFS), Breadth First Search (BFS), Depth First Iterative Deepening (DFID). Heuristic Search â€“ Generate and Test, Best First Search, Beam Search, Hill Climbing, A* Algorithm.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Advanced Problem Solving (7 hrs)**
Problem Reduction Search â€“ AND/OR Graphs, AO* Algorithm, Constraint Satisfaction Problems, Means-Ends Analysis. Stochastic Search Methods â€“ Simulated Annealing, Particle Swarm Optimization. Game Playing â€“ Minimax Algorithm, Alpha-Beta Pruning.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Knowledge and Reasoning (7 hrs)**
Building a Knowledge Base â€“ Propositional Logic, First Order Logic. Inference in First Order Logic, Resolution and Refutation Proofs, Theorem Proving in First Order Logic. Planning and Partial Order Planning. Uncertain Knowledge and Reasoning â€“ Probability Theory, Bayesian Networks.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Learning (7 hrs)**
Overview of Learning Methods â€“ Supervised, Unsupervised and Semi-Supervised Learning. K-Means Clustering Algorithm, Decision Trees, Neural Networks, Deep Learning.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Advanced Topics (7 hrs)**
Introduction to Computer Vision, Natural Language Processing, Expert Systems, Robotics, Genetic Algorithm.

ðŸ“š **Text / Reference Books**
1. Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach â€” S. Russell & P. Norvig, Prentice Hall
2. Artificial Intelligence â€” E. Rich, K. Knight & S. B. Nair, TMH
3. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning â€” C. Bishop, Springer
4. Introduction to Artificial Intelligence and Expert Systems â€” D. W. Patterson, Prentice Hall
5. Robotics and AI: An Introduction to Applied Machine Intelligence â€” A. C. Staugaard Jr., Prentice Hall
6. Prolog Programming for Artificial Intelligence â€” I. Bratko, Addison-Wesley
7. Neural Networks and Learning Machines â€” S. O. Haykin, Prentice Hall
8. Speech and Language Processing â€” D. Jurafsky & J. H. Martin, Prentice Hall

Computer Network.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157503**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Introduction to Computer Networks (4 hrs)**
Overview of Data Communication and Networking, OSI Reference Model, TCP/IP Protocol Suite, Network Architecture and Physical Topology.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Physical Layer (10 hrs)**
Analog and Digital Signals, Transmission Impairment, Data Rate Limits, Performance Analysis of a Network. Representation and Synchronization of Bits, Analog and Digital Transmission. Multiplexing and Spreading Techniques. Guided Transmission Media. Circuit Switching, Packet Switching and Virtual Circuit Switching.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Data Link Layer (10 hrs)**
Framing, Flow Control and Error Control (Noiseless and Noisy Channel Protocols), Point-to-Point Protocol. Random Access Protocols â€“ Pure ALOHA, Slotted ALOHA, CSMA/CD, CSMA/CA. Controlled Access Protocols â€“ Bit-Map, Polling, Token Passing. Channelization â€“ TDMA, FDMA, CDMA. Physical Addressing and Ethernet. Connecting LANs and Virtual LANs.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Network Layer (7 hrs)**
Internet Protocol Version 4 and Version 6. Address Mapping â€“ ARP, RARP, BOOTP and DHCP. ICMP and IGMP. Routing Algorithms.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Transport Layer (7 hrs)**
User Datagram Protocol (UDP), Transmission Control Protocol (TCP). Congestion Control and Quality of Service (QoS). Client-Server Model and Socket Interface.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Application Layer (4 hrs)**
Domain Name System (DNS), Remote Logging, Electronic Mail (SMTP, POP), File Transfer Protocol (FTP), Introduction to World Wide Web (WWW) and HTTP.

ðŸ“š **Suggested Books**
1. Data Communication and Networking (4th Edition) â€” B. Forouzan, McGraw-Hill
2. Computer Networks (5th Edition) â€” A. S. Tanenbaum, Pearson Education Asia

ðŸ“š **Suggested Reference Books**
1. Data and Computer Communication (8th Edition) â€” W. Stallings, PHI
2. Communication Networks: Fundamental Concepts and Key Architectures (2nd Edition) â€” A. L. Garcia & I. Widjaja, Tata McGraw-Hill
3. A Course in Computer Networks (3rd Edition) â€” S. Sharma, Kataria

Machine Learning.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157504**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Introduction (7 hrs)**
Types of Learning, Common Aspects of Machine Learning Approach â€“ Model and Parameters, Bias-Variance Tradeoff. Training, Testing and Validation Datasets, Error Function. Curse of Dimensionality. Predictive Analysis using Regression.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Python Basics for Machine Learning (7 hrs)**
Fundamental Data Types in Python, Looping and Decision-Making Constructs, Functions, Classes, File Handling, Database Access, Output Formatting, Modules. Statistics Module, NumPy, Introduction to Popular Machine Learning Libraries â€“ TensorFlow and Keras.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Unsupervised Learning (7 hrs)**
Clustering Techniques, K-Means Algorithm, Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) and Expectation Maximization (EM) Algorithm. Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) â€“ Unsupervised Dimensionality Reduction Technique.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Supervised Learning (7 hrs)**
Classification Techniques â€“ K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), NaÃ¯ve Bayes, Decision Tree. Support Vector Machine (SVM) â€“ Soft Margin, Hard Margin and Kernel Trick. Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA) â€“ Supervised Dimensionality Reduction Technique.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Ensemble and Reinforcement Learning (7 hrs)**
Ensemble Learning Techniques â€“ Bagging, Random Forest and Boosting. Reinforcement Learning â€“ Q-Learning and SARSA Algorithms.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Neural Networks (7 hrs)**
Introduction to Neural Networks, Perceptron Model, Learning Rules and Activation Functions, Multilayer Feed-Forward Networks, Backpropagation Algorithm, Introduction to Feedback Networks.

ðŸ“š **Text / Reference Books**
1. Machine Learning â€” Tom Mitchell, McGraw-Hill
2. Machine Learning: An Algorithmic Perspective â€” Stephen Marsland, Chapman and Hall/CRC, 2011
3. Introduction to Artificial Neural Systems â€” Jacek M. Zurada, West Publishing Company, 1992
4. A Tutorial on Support Vector Machines for Pattern Recognition â€” Christopher Burges, Data Mining and Knowledge Discovery, 1998

Pattern Recognition.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157506**
ðŸ“˜ **Program Elective-I**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Introduction to Pattern Recognition (7 hrs)**
Definition and Applications of Pattern Recognition, Supervised vs. Unsupervised Learning, Statistical vs. Structural Pattern Recognition, Pattern Recognition System Design, Overview of Feature Extraction and Feature Selection.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Statistical Pattern Recognition (7 hrs)**
Bayes Decision Theory, Maximum Likelihood Estimation, Bayesian Classifier, NaÃ¯ve Bayes Classifier, Parametric and Non-Parametric Approaches, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Probabilistic Graphical Models.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Feature Extraction and Dimensionality Reduction (7 hrs)**
Feature Selection Techniques, Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Linear Discriminant Analysis (LDA), Independent Component Analysis (ICA), Singular Value Decomposition (SVD), Feature Engineering for Pattern Recognition.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Machine Learning for Pattern Recognition (7 hrs)**
Support Vector Machines (SVM), Decision Trees, Random Forest, Neural Networks (MLP, CNNs), Deep Learning Approaches, Autoencoders, Performance Evaluation Metrics â€“ Precision, Recall, F1-Score, ROC Curve.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Clustering and Unsupervised Learning (7 hrs)**
K-Means Clustering, Hierarchical Clustering, DBSCAN, Gaussian Mixture Models (GMM), Self-Organizing Maps (SOM), Hidden Markov Models (HMM), Applications of Clustering in Pattern Recognition.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Applications and Emerging Trends (7 hrs)**
Pattern Recognition in Image Processing, Speech Recognition, Biometrics, Natural Language Processing (NLP), Object Detection and Recognition, AI-Driven Pattern Recognition, Ethical Considerations in Pattern Recognition.

ðŸ“š **Textbooks**
1. Pattern Classification â€” Richard O. Duda, Peter E. Hart, David G. Stork, Wiley
2. Pattern Recognition â€” Sergios Theodoridis, Konstantinos Koutroumbas, Academic Press
3. Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning â€” C. M. Bishop, Springer

ðŸ“š **Reference Books**
1. Neural Networks and Learning Machines â€” S. Haykin, Pearson
2. Neural Networks for Pattern Recognition â€” Christopher Bishop, Oxford University Press
3. Introduction to Statistical Learning Theory â€” S. V. N. Vishwanathan, Springer
4. Statistical Pattern Recognition: A Review â€” Anil K. Jain, Robert P. Duin, Jianchang Mao, Elsevier
5. The Elements of Statistical Learning â€” Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani, Jerome Friedman, Springer

Software Engineering.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157507**
ðŸ“˜ **Program Elective-I**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Introduction (8 hrs)**
What is Software Engineering and its History, Software Crisis, Evolution of a Programming System Product, Characteristics of Software, Brooksâ€™ No Silver Bullet, Software Myths. Software Development Life Cycles (SDLC): Software Development Process, Code-and-Fix Model, Waterfall Model, Evolutionary Model, Incremental Implementation, Prototyping, Spiral Model, Software Reuse, Critical Comparison of SDLC Models. Introduction to Non-Traditional Software Development Processes: Rational Unified Process (RUP), Rapid Application Development (RAD), Agile Development Process.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Requirements Engineering (8 hrs)**
Importance of Requirement Analysis, User Needs, Software Features and Software Requirements. Classes of User Requirements: Enduring and Volatile. Sub-Phases of Requirement Analysis, Functional and Non-Functional Requirements, Barriers to Eliciting User Requirements. Software Requirements Document and SRS Standards. Requirements Engineering, Case Study of SRS for a Real-Time System. Tools for Requirements Gathering: Document Flow Chart, Decision Table, Decision Tree. Introduction to Non-Traditional Requirements.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Software Design (6 hrs)**
Goals of Good Software Design, Design Strategies and Methodologies, Data-Oriented Software Design, Coupling and Cohesion, Modular Structure and Packaging. Structured Analysis: Data Flow Diagrams (DFD), Data Dictionary. Structured Design: Structure Charts. Object-Oriented Design, Top-Down and Bottom-Up Approaches, Unified Modeling Language (UML), UML Diagrams, Design Patterns.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Software Project Management (6 hrs)**
Overview of Project Manager Responsibilities and Project Planning. Software Measurement and Metrics: Lines of Code (LOC), Function Point (FP) Based Measures. Size-Oriented Measures: Halsteadâ€™s Software Science. Project Size Estimation Metrics and Techniques, COCOMO Model. Staffing Level Estimation, Scheduling, Organization and Team Structures, Risk Management.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Software Coding and Testing (7 hrs)**
Development Activities: Selecting a Programming Language, Coding Guidelines, Writing Code, Code Documentation. Testing Process, Test Case Design. Functional Testing: Boundary Value Analysis, Equivalence Class Testing, Decision Table Testing, Cause-Effect Graphing. Structural Testing, Cyclomatic Complexity Measures, Control Flow Graphs, Path Testing, Data Flow and Mutation Testing. Unit Testing, Integration Testing, System Testing, Debugging, Alpha and Beta Testing, Testing Tools and Standards.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Software Maintenance, Reliability and Quality Management (7 hrs)**
Management of Software Maintenance, Maintenance Process and Models, Regression Testing, Reverse Engineering, Software Reengineering, Configuration Management and Documentation. Software Reliability and Quality Management: Introduction to Reliability and Reliability Metrics. Overview of Software Quality Management System, ISO 9000, SEI CMM.

ðŸ“š **Text / Reference Books**
1. Software Engineering: A Practitionerâ€™s Approach â€” R. S. Pressman, McGraw-Hill
2. Fundamentals of Software Engineering (4th Edition) â€” Rajib Mall, PHI
3. A Concise Introduction to Software Engineering â€” Pankaj Jalote
4. Zero Defect Software â€” G. G. Schulmeyer, McGraw-Hill
5. Object-Oriented Modeling and Design â€” J. Rumbaugh, Prentice Hall
6. Software Engineering â€” K. K. Aggarwal & Yogesh Singh, New Age International Publishers

Emerging Web Technology.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157508**
ðŸ“˜ **Program Elective-I**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Introduction to Web Development and AI (8 hrs)**
Overview of Web Programming, Fundamentals of Web Development including Client-Side and Server-Side Scripting Languages. Introduction to Artificial Intelligence (AI): Definition, Scope and Applications of AI in Various Fields. Intersection of Web Development and AI â€“ How AI Technologies Enhance Web Applications and User Experience. Tools and Technologies for Web Development and AI Integration.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Front-End Development and AI Integration (8 hrs)**
Introduction to HTML: History, HTML Documents, Basic Structure, Creating an HTML Document, Features and Limitations, Markup Tags, Headings, Paragraphs, Line Breaks, Formatting Tags. Working with Text, Lists, Tables and Frames. Hyperlinks, Images, Image Formats (Quality, Size, Type), Importing Images, Forms and Controls. Responsive Web Design Techniques for Multiple Devices. Introduction to AI Libraries and APIs for Front-End Integration.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) (8 hrs)**
Concept of CSS, Creating Style Sheets, CSS Properties. Styling Backgrounds, Text and Fonts. Working with Block Elements, Lists and Tables. CSS ID and Class. Box Model â€“ Border, Padding and Margin Properties. Advanced CSS â€“ Grouping, Dimensions, Display, Positioning, Floating, Alignment, Pseudo-Classes, Navigation Bar, Image Sprites, Attribute Selectors. CSS Colors, Page Layout and Site Design.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 Web Publishing, Multimedia and Hosting (6 hrs)**
Creating and Managing Websites, Website Structure and Page Titles, Themes and Publishing Websites. Multimedia: Audio Files, Video Files and Acceptable Formats (MPEG, QuickTime, Video for Windows). Screen Control Attributes â€“ Width, Height, Align. Start Control Attributes â€“ Start, FileOpen, Loop, LoopDelay, MouseOver. Digital Images and Image Representation. Image Formats â€“ TIFF, BMP, JPG/JPEG, GIF, PIC, PDF. Hosting Basics and Types of Hosting.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Introduction to React and Core Concepts (6 hrs)**
Overview of React, JSX, React Components. Props, State and Component Lifecycle Methods.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 React Router, State Management and Hooks (6 hrs)**
Navigation and Routing in Single Page Applications. Context API and Redux for Global State Management. React Hooks â€“ useState, useEffect and Custom Hooks.

ðŸ“š **Text / Reference Books**
1. Building Intelligent Web Applications: How to Get Started with Artificial Intelligence-Driven Web Applications â€” Mark Watson, 2019
2. Web Development with Artificial Intelligence â€” Ibrahim Naji, 2020
3. Learning React: Functional Web Development with React and Redux â€” Alex Banks & Eve Porcello
4. React Design Patterns and Best Practices â€” Carlos Santana RoldÃ¡n
5. AI for Web Development: Leverage the Power of Machine Learning and Deep Learning to Build Smart Web Applications â€” Sandeep Kumar Patel, 2019
6. Full Stack React: The Complete Guide to ReactJS and Friends â€” Accomazzo, Murray & Lerner

Digital Signal Processing.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157509**
ðŸ“˜ **Program Elective-I**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Unit-1.0 Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) (7 hrs)**
Z-Transform and Discrete-Time Fourier Transform (DTFT). Frequency Domain Sampling (Sampling of DTFT). Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT) and Inverse DFT, Zero Padding. DFT as a Linear Transformation (Matrix Method) and its Properties. Spectrum Analysis using DFT. Filtering of Long Data Sequences using DFT â€“ Overlap-Save Method and Overlap-Add Method.

ðŸ“™ **Unit-2.0 Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) â€“ Radix-2 Algorithms (8 hrs)**
Decimation-in-Time (DIT-FFT) Algorithm, Decimation-in-Frequency (DIF-FFT) Algorithm. Inverse DFT using FFT Algorithms. Goertzel Algorithm, Chirp-Z Transform Algorithm.

ðŸ“• **Unit-3.0 Filter Concepts (8 hrs)**
Frequency Response and Filter Characteristics, Phase Delay and Group Delay. Zero-Phase Filter, Linear-Phase Filter. Simple FIR Filters and Simple IIR Filters. All-Pass Filter, Minimum-Phase System. Averaging Filter, Comb Filter, Digital Resonator, Notch Filter, Digital Sinusoidal Oscillator.

ðŸ“’ **Unit-4.0 FIR and IIR Digital Filters (5 hrs)**
Desirability of Linear-Phase Filters. Frequency Response of Linear-Phase FIR Filters. Filter Specifications â€“ Absolute and Relative Specifications, Analog Filter Specifications. Design Techniques â€“ Windowing Method, Frequency Sampling Method, Digital Hilbert Transformer. Analog Filters â€“ Butterworth and Chebyshev Approximation. Bilinear Transformation Method, Warping Effect, Spectral Transformation. Design of Low-Pass, High-Pass, Band-Pass and Band-Elimination Filters.

ðŸ““ **Unit-5.0 Realization of Digital Filters (7 hrs)**
FIR Filter Structures â€“ Direct Form, Cascade Form, Linear-Phase Form, FIR Lattice Structure. IIR Filter Structures â€“ Direct Form-I, Direct Form-II, Cascade Form, Parallel Form, All-Pole Lattice Structure, Lattice-Ladder (Pole-Zero) Structure.

ðŸ“” **Unit-6.0 Multirate Signal Processing (7 hrs)**
Decimation and Interpolation. Polyphase Decomposition. Digital Filter Banks. Nyquist Filters. Two-Channel Quadrature Mirror Filter (QMF).

ðŸ“š **Text / Reference Books**
1. Digital Signal Processing â€” Alan V. Oppenheim & Ronald W. Schafer, PHI
2. Digital Signal Processing: A Computer-Based Approach â€” S. K. Mitra, Tata McGraw-Hill
3. Digital Signal Processing â€” John G. Proakis & Dimitris G. Manolakis, Pearson

Database Management System Lab.text:
ðŸ“˜ **Paper Code: 157501P**
ðŸ“˜ **Semester: V**

ðŸ“— **Laboratory Work / Experiments**

1. Selection of a suitable case study and formulation of the problem statement.

2. Conceptual Database Design using ER Diagrams: Identifying entities, attributes, keys and relationships between entities, cardinalities, generalization and specialization. *(Note: Student is required to submit a document containing the ER Diagram to the lab teacher.)*

3. Conversion of ER Model to Relational Model: Representing entities and relationships in tabular form, representing attributes as columns, and identifying primary and foreign keys. *(Note: Student must submit a document showing database tables derived from the ER Model.)*

4. Normalization: Removing redundancies and anomalies in relational tables by normalizing the database up to Third Normal Form (3NF).

5. Creation of Tables using SQL: Overview of SQL tools, SQL data types, creating tables with primary and foreign keys, altering tables and dropping tables.

6. Practicing Data Manipulation Language (DML) Commands: INSERT, SELECT, UPDATE and DELETE.

7. Practicing Advanced SQL Queries using ANY, ALL, IN, EXISTS, NOT EXISTS, UNION, INTERSECT and CONSTRAINTS.

8. Practicing Subqueries (Nested and Correlated) and Joins (Inner Join, Outer Join and Equi Join).

9. Practicing Aggregate Functions and Views: COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, MIN, GROUP BY, HAVING clauses, creation and deletion of views.

10. Practicing Triggers: Creation of triggers, insertion using triggers, deletion using triggers and updating using triggers.

ðŸ“š **Outcome**
Students will gain hands-on experience in database design, SQL programming, normalization, query processing and database automation using triggers.
